# Introduction to Python IV

<span class="lead"> </span>

One of the core concepts in OOP is that of *inheritance* which allows us to define a hierarchical relationship between different classes. Another is that of *association* that is concerned with objects that refer to other objects. We’ll cover both of those in this module.

**At the end of this module, you should be able to:**

-   demonstrate an understanding of inheritance through appropriate method overriding and use of super()
-   demonstrate an understanding of association through appropriate class design

#### Pro Tip

If you are going to copy/paste text from an email, be sure to do so without formatting or else: convert the text to “normal” and be sure the text color is “black”

## <a href="#learn" id="learn" class="anchor"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Learn

#### Learn to demonstrate an understanding of inheritance through appropriate method overriding and use of super()

***Inheritance relationships*** can be defined between classes in situations where more specific child classes extend the functionality of more general parent classes. These hierarchies help us write well-organized code and can allow for code re-use.

##### Overview

### Inheritance

When you’re attempting to solve a programming problem, you will often find an existing class that does *almost* what you need. If you changed the class, you could end up breaking something that used to work.

You could also create a new class and copy and paste from the old one the functionality that you want to borrow. Then, you could add the new functionality that you need. This could end up creating some confusion in the code if these two classes are similar. What would you do if you changed the functionality in the original class? You’d likely want to track down the correlating code in the new class and change that. You can see how this would create some maintenance challenges in your code base.

Instead of changing the old class or cutting and pasting to create a similar class, you can use *inheritance* to solve your problem. When you use inheritance to create your new class, you can use all the code from the old class (copying none of it) and you can also add the additional functionality you need.

In the new class, we only need to define what we add or change from the old class. We call the original class either the *parent, superclass,* or *base class*. We call the new class the *child, subclass*, or *derived class*.

Let’s see how this works in code:

    >>> class Bicycle():
    ...     pass
    ...
    >>> class Specialized(Bicycle):
    ...     pass
    ...
    >>> a_bike = Bicycle()
    >>> a_specialized = Specialized()
    >>>

In the example above, a `Specialized` *is a* `Bicycle`. The child class is a specialization of a parent class. We created this relationship by passing the `Bicycle` class into the `Specialized` class definition. `a_specialized` is an instance of class `Specialized` but it also inherited whatever the `Bicycle` class can do. In this example, both these classes are useless. Let’s now fill out our code more:

    >>> class Bicycle():
    ...     def exclaim(self):
    ...         print("I'm a Bicycle!")
    ...
    >>> class Specialized(Bicycle):
    ...     pass
    ...
    >>> a_bicycle = Bicycle()
    >>> a_specialized = Specialized()
    >>> a_bicycle.exclaim()
    I'm a Bicycle!
    >>> a_specialized.exclaim()
    I'm a Bicycle!
    >>>

By setting up the parent-child relationship when we defined the classes, now any instance of the `Specialized` class has access to the methods on the parent class `Bicycle`.

### Overriding a Method

Let’s override the `exclaim` method so that an instance of `Specialized` will tell us what it is:

    >>> class Bicycle():
    ...     def exclaim(self):
    ...         print("I'm a Bicycle!")
    ...
    >>> class Specialized(Bicycle):
    ...     def exclaim(self):
    ...         print("I'm a Specialized! I'm a more specialized version of a Bicycle!")
    ...
    >>> a_bike = Bicycle()
    >>> a_specialized = Specialized()
    >>> a_bike.exclaim()
    I'm a Bicycle!
    >>> a_specialized.exclaim()
    I'm a Specialized! I'm a more specialized version of a Bicycle!
    >>>

Notice that just by defining a new `exclaim` method on the child `Specialized` class, any instances of the child class will now use that method instead of the parent `Bicycle` class’s `exclaim` method.

It is important to note here that method overriding is optional. If a child class does not override a parent method, then when the target method is called on the child class, the parent method is used. Child classes can override methods on a parent class, however, the reverse is not true. Parent classes cannot override methods on their children.

### Using `super`

You’ve now seen how the child class can override a method from a parent. But, what if we needed to call the parent method?

Let’s create a `Student` parent class and a `Graduate` child class. The `Graduate` class needs everything a normal `Student` has, but also needs to store a `graduation_date`. We will use inheritance to set up this relationship.

    >>> class Student():
    ...     def __init__(self, name):
    ...         self.name = name
    ...
    >>> class Graduate(Student):
    ...     def __init__(self, name, graduation_date):
    ...         super().__init__(name)
    ...         self.graduation_date = graduation_date
    ...
    >>>

By defining the `__init__` method in `Graduate`, we are overriding the `__init__` method in `Student`. But, we still want the `Student` portion of our child class to run its initialization, even when instantiating a `Graduate`. Inside the child `Graduate`, to access the parent `Student`’s method, we use `super()`. Then, after running the parent initializer, we run the `Graduate` specific initialization behavior.

One thing to notice is that when we called `super().__init__()` in the child class, we didn’t have to pass along `self`. The `self` argument is passed to the parent class automatically.

Let’s create an instance of `Graduate`.

    >>> john_lennon = Graduate('John Lennon', 'December 8, 1980')
    >>> john_lennon.name
    'John Lennon'
    >>> john_lennon.graduation_date
    'December 8, 1980'
    >>>

##### Challenge

Open a Python interpreter and complete the following:

1.  Define a parent class with at least two attributes and a method that prints out some of this information.
2.  Define two child classes. In each child class, define at least one additional attribute and a method that overrides the parent method to print out a more specific version of what the object instance is.
3.  Instantiate an instance of the parent class and store the instance in a variable.
4.  Instantiate an instance of each of the child classes and store each in a variable.
5.  Interact with the instances to test out the methods you defined to make sure the overriding was effective.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

#### Learn to demonstrate an understanding of association through appropriate class design

Now that you have explored inheritance relationships, we will look at another category of class relationships - ***association***.

##### Overview

Composition in programming is when we collect several objects together to create a new one. Composition is usually the right choice when one object is part of another object. It’s often said that if inheritance establishes an ***“is-a”*** relationship, then composition establishes a ***“has-a”*** relationship.

To illustrate, imagine you’ve created a `Duck` class. A duck is made up of many parts, or a duck ***has*** many parts. So, a `Tail` class would not inherit from the `Duck` class, rather a `Duck` would be composed of the `Tail` class (and many others like `Bill`, `Eye`, `Foot`, etc.).

I’m sure you are already wondering, what would this look like in Python code? Let’s define a few classes to illustrate.

    class Bill():
        def __init__(self, description):
            self.description = description


    class Tail():
        def __init__(self, length):
            self.length = length


    class Duck():
        def __init__(self, bill, tail):
            self.bill = bill
            self.tail = tail

        def about(self):
            print(
                f"This duck has a {self.bill.description} and a {self.tail.length} tail.")


    duck = Duck(Bill('wide orange'), Tail('long'))
    duck.about()

Notice how none of the classes have an inheritance relationship with the others. However, the `Duck` class expects to receive instances of the `Bill` and `Tail` classes when it is initialized. You can tell this is a composition relationship because you can accurately describe the program by stating that the `Duck` ***has a*** `Bill` and `Tail`.

### Aggregation

Aggregation is almost exactly like composition. The difference is that aggregate objects can exist independently. It would be impossible for a bill to be associated with a different duck. But what if there was a `Collar` or `Leash` class? A `Duck` *could* have a collar or leash (although it’d be strange I admit), and, unlike a `Bill` or `Tail`, the collar or leash could exist independently from the `Duck`.

Another way to differentiate between aggregation and composition is to consider the object’s lifespan. If the outside object (`Duck` in this example) controls when the inside objects are created and destroyed (like `Bill` or `Tail`), composition is most suitable. If the related object (like `Leash` or `Collar`) can outlast the composition object (`Duck` in this example), then an aggregate relationship makes more sense.

Keep in mind that composition is aggregation; aggregation is just a more general form of composition. Any composite relationship is also an aggregate relationship, but the reverse is not true.

##### Challenge

1.  Think of your own example of objects that represent a ***has-a*** relationship. Define a class for each of the objects in such a way that accurately represents the composition relationship.

2.  In your own words, describe the difference between composition and aggregation in class relationships.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Demonstrate Mastery

To demonstrate mastery of this module, you need to complete and pass a code review on each of the following:

-   Objective challenge:

    Open a Python interpreter and complete the following:

    1.  Define a parent class with at least two attributes and a method that prints out some of this information.
    2.  Define two child classes. In each child class, define at least one additional attribute and a method that overrides the parent method to print out a more specific version of what the object instance is.
    3.  Instantiate an instance of the parent class and store the instance in a variable.
    4.  Instantiate an instance of each of the child classes and store each in a variable.
    5.  Interact with the instances to test out the methods you defined to make sure the overriding was effective.

-   Objective challenge:
    1.  Think of your own example of objects that represent a ***has-a*** relationship. Define a class for each of the objects in such a way that accurately represents the composition relationship.

    2.  In your own words, describe the difference between composition and aggregation in class relationships.

-   Project: Intro to Python II
